data.name: Msg_AlbumDoesNotExist_Dtl
data.value: Attention: The requested album does not exist in the database, so the top level album is shown instead.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user requests an album that doesn't exist. Specifically, a query string parameter named aid was passed to the page, but no record in the Album table exists with the specified album ID (the database field is named AlbumID).

data.name: Msg_AlbumNameAndSummaryExceededMaxLength_Dtl
data.value: Attention: Both the album title and summary you entered exceeded the maximum number of characters, and the text was truncated. The album title must be less than {0} characters, and the album summary must be less than {1} characters.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user enters an album name and summary whose length exceeds the field's definition.

data.name: Msg_AlbumNameExceededMaxLength_Dtl
data.value: Attention: The album title you entered exceeded the maximum number of characters, and was truncated. The album title must be less than {0} characters.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user enters an album title whose length exceeds the field's definition.

data.name: Msg_AlbumSummaryExceededMaxLength_Dtl
data.value: Attention: The album summary you entered exceeded the maximum number of characters, and was truncated. The album summary must be less than {0} characters.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user enters an album summary whose length exceeds the field's definition.

data.name: Msg_CannotAssignThumbnailNoObjectsExistInAlbum_Dtl
data.value: Attention: This album does not currently contain any media objects. Therefore, a thumbnail cannot be assigned to this album.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> The message detail that is displayed when user tries to assign a thumbnail image for an album that does not contain any media objects.

data.name: Msg_CannotCopyNoObjectsExistInAlbum_Dtl
data.value: Attention: This album does not contain any media objects. Therefore, none can be copied.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user tries to copy gallery objects in an album that does not contain any media objects.

data.name: Msg_CannotDeleteHiResImagesNoObjectsExistInAlbum_Dtl
data.value: Attention: This album does not contain any images.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user tries to delete high-res images in an album that does not contain any images.

data.name: Msg_CannotDeleteObjectsNoObjectsExistInAlbum_Dtl
data.value: Attention: This album does not contain any albums or media objects. Therefore, there is nothing to delete.
data.comment: <2009.05.13> Displayed when user tries to delete gallery objects in an album that is empty.

data.name: Msg_CannotEditCaptionsNoEditableObjectsExistInAlbum_Dtl
data.value: Attention: This album contains no media objects. Therefore, it has no captions to edit.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user tries to edit captions for an album that does not contain any media objects.

data.name: Msg_CannotMoveNoObjectsExistInAlbum_Dtl
data.value: Attention: This album does not contain any media objects. Therefore, there is nothing to be moved.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user tries to move gallery objects in an album that does not contain any media objects.

data.name: Msg_CannotRearrangeNoObjectsExistInAlbum_Dtl
data.value: Attention: This album does not contain any media objects. Therefore, there are none to rearrange.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user tries to rearrange gallery objects in an album that doesn't contain any media objects.

data.name: Msg_CannotRotateNoRotateableObjectsExistInAlbum_Hdr
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user tries to rotate images for an album that contain any images.

data.name: Msg_CaptionExceededMaxLength_Dtl
data.value: Attention: The caption you entered exceeded the maximum allowed length, and was truncated. A caption must be less than {0} characters.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user enters a caption whose length exceeds the field's definition.

data.name: Msg_HiResImagesSuccessfullyDeleted_Dtl
data.value: The high resolution versions of the image(s) you chose have been successfully deleted.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user successfully deletes one or more high resolution images from an album, leaving only the compressed and thumbnail versions.

data.name: Msg_MediaObjectDoesNotExist_Dtl
data.value: Attention: The requested media object does not exist in the database, so the top level album is shown instead.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user requests a media object that doesn't exist. Specifically, a query string parameter named moid was passed to the page, but no record in the MediaObject table exists with the specified media object ID (the database field is named MediaObjectID).

data.name: Msg_NoScriptDefaultText
data.value: Attention: This web site requires javascript for some features, such as running a slide show and navigating between media objects. Turn on javascript for full website functionality.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> This text is inserted into a <noscript> on any page that has a <script> tag. It will be displayed by the browser when javascript is disabled on the user's browser.

data.name: Msg_ObjectsSuccessfullyDeleted_Dtl
data.value: The media object(s) you chose have been successfully deleted.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user successfully deletes one or more media objects from an album.

data.name: Msg_OneOrMoreCaptionsExceededMaxLength_Dtl
data.value: Attention: One or more captions you entered exceeded the maximum allowed length, and was truncated. A caption must be less than {0} characters.
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when user enters a caption whose length exceeds the field's definition.

data.name: Msg_SynchronizationFailure_Dtl
data.comment: <2007.12.08> Displayed when an error occurs when synchronizing database with media object files on hard drive.

data.name: MediaObjectHtmlBuilder_Ctor_InvalidAlbumId_Msg
data.value: Argument Exception: The constructor for MediaObjectHtmlBuilder requires parameter "albumId" to be greater than zero. The albumId should contain the album ID for the album containing the media object for which the HTML is to be generated. Value passed was {0}.

data.name: MediaObjectHtmlBuilder_Ctor_InvalidBrowsers_Msg
data.value: Argument Exception: A valid list of browsers must be passed to the MediaObjectHtmlBuilder constructor. The value passed was either null or contained zero elements. Typically you will call ToArray() on the Request.Browser.Browsers property for the "browsers" parameter.

data.name: MediaObjectHtmlBuilder_Ctor_InvalidHeight_Msg
data.value: Argument Exception: The constructor for MediaObjectHtmlBuilder requires parameter "height" to be greater than or equal to zero. Value passed was {0}.

data.name: MediaObjectHtmlBuilder_Ctor_InvalidMediaObjectId_Msg
data.value: Argument Exception: The constructor for MediaObjectHtmlBuilder requires parameter "mediaObjectId" to be greater than zero. The mediaObjectId should contain the media object ID for which the HTML is to be generated. Value passed was {0}.

data.name: MediaObjectHtmlBuilder_Ctor_InvalidMimeType_Msg
data.value: Argument Exception: A valid mime type must be passed to the MediaObjectHtmlBuilder constructor. The value passed was either null or of type NullMimeType.

data.name: MediaObjectHtmlBuilder_Ctor_InvalidWidth_Msg
data.value: Argument Exception: The constructor for MediaObjectHtmlBuilder requires parameter "width" to be greater than or equal to zero. Value passed was {0}.

data.name: Error_GetMediaObjectUrl_Ex_Msg1
data.value: The method GalleryServerPro.Web.Pages.GalleryPage.GetGalleryObjectUrl() requires parameter displayType to be a DisplayObjectType enumeration item with one of these values: Thumbnail, Optimized, Original. Instead, the value {0} was passed.

data.name: Site_Editable_Content_Tooltip
data.comment: <2007.12.08> This is the tooltip that appears when a user with edit permission hovers the mouse over an editable portion of the screen.

data.name: UC_Album_Header_Album_Date_Range_Separator_Text
data.comment: <2007.12.08> This is the text that appears between the start and end dates for an album. For example, specifying the word "to" results in "06/30/09 to 07/15/09"

data.name: UC_Album_Header_Album_Summary_Max_Length_Text
data.comment: <2007.12.08> This is the text that informs the user of the maximum number of allowed characters for an album summary. The string must contain {0}! The {0} is used in a String.Format() method and is replaced with the maximum number of characters. For example, specifying "({0} max)" results in "(1500 max)", assuming the maximum number of charactesr for an album summary is 1500.

data.name: UC_Album_Header_Album_Title_Max_Length_Text
data.comment: <2007.12.08> This is the text that informs the user of the maximum number of allowed characters for an album title. The string must contain {0}! The {0} is used in a String.Format() method and is replaced with the maximum number of characters. For example, specifying "({0} max)" results in "(200 max)", assuming the maximum number of charactesr for an album title is 200.

data.name: Task_Create_Album_Missing_Title_Text
data.comment: <2008.12.31> This is the message displayed to the user when attempting to create an album and no title has been entered. HTML tags are optional.

data.name: Task_Create_Album_Title_Max_Length_Text
data.comment: <2007.12.08> This is the text that informs the user of the maximum number of allowed characters for an album title. The string must contain {0}! The {0} is used in a String.Format() method and is replaced with the maximum number of characters. For example, specifying "({0} chars max)" results in "(200 chars max)", assuming the maximum number of charactesr for an album title is 200.

data.name: Task_Delete_HiRes_Body_Text
data.value: You can reduce hard disk usage by deleting the high resolution versions of your images. Select the image(s) for which you would like to delete the corresponding high resolution image. The thumbnail and compressed versions will not be deleted.

data.name: Task_Delete_HiRes_Header_Text
data.value: Delete one or more high-res images from this album.

data.name: Task_Delete_HiRes_No_HiRes_Image_Text
data.comment: <2009.05.13> This is the message displayed in place of a checkbox when the image does not have a corresponding high resolution version that can be deleted.

data.name: Task_Delete_HiRes_Ok_Button_Tooltip
data.value: Delete any high-res images associated with the selected media objects (cannot be undone)

data.name: Task_Delete_HiRes_Potential_Savings_Text
data.comment: <2007.12.08> This is the message that indicates the amount of hard disk space that may be reclaimed if the user deletes all the high resolution images in the current album. Requires two formatting placeholders: {0} is replaced with the savings in KB; {1} is replaced with the savings in MB. Ex: If the string is "Potential savings: {0} KB ({1} MB)", it may be rendered as "Potential savings: 2048 KB (2.00 MB)"

data.name: Task_Delete_HiRes_Warning
data.value: WARNING: The high resolution images will be permanently deleted from the web server! If these images are important, make sure you have a copy safely stored elsewhere.

data.name: Cfg_allowHtmlInTitlesAndCaptions_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates whether to allow limited HTML in titles, captions and external media objects (for example, embed code for a YouTube video). The list of valid HTML tags and attributes is defined below. When checked, any HTML that is not approved is automatically removed when the user attempts to enter it. For external media objects, the user is alerted to the invalid tags and the object is not added.

When unchecked, HTML is not accepted in any user-editable field. This is the most secure and reliable way to prevent malicious attacks such as cross-site scripting.

Unchecking this option does not remove HTML from existing objects. However, new and changed album and media object titles and captions will be stripped of HTML when they are saved.

galleryserverpro.config property: allowHtmlInTitlesAndCaptions

data.name: Cfg_emailFromAddress_Bdy
data.value:
E-mails sent from Gallery Server Pro (error reports and password change notifications) will appear to be sent from this e-mail address.

galleryserverpro.config property: emailFromAddress

data.name: Cfg_emailFromName_Bdy
data.value:
E-mails sent from Gallery Server Pro (error reports and password change notifications) will appear to be sent from this person.

galleryserverpro.config property: emailFromName

data.name: Cfg_emailToAddress_Bdy
data.value:
E-mails sent from Gallery Server Pro are sent to this e-mail address.

galleryserverpro.config property: emailToAddress

data.name: Cfg_emailToName_Bdy
data.value:
E-mails sent from Gallery Server Pro are addressed to this person.

galleryserverpro.config property: emailToName

data.name: Cfg_galleryId_Bdy
data.value:
The value that uniquely identifies the gallery for this website. Each web application is associated with a single gallery.

galleryserverpro.config property: galleryId

data.name: Cfg_pageHeaderTextUrl_Bdy
data.value:
The URL the user will be directed to when she clicks the gallery\\'s title text. It is optional: if not present, no link will be rendered.

Examples:

  • http://www.mysite.com
  • / (the root of the web site)
  • ~/ (the top level album)

galleryserverpro.config property: pageHeaderTextUrl

data.name: Cfg_pageHeaderText_Bdy
data.value:
The header text that appears at the top of each web page.

galleryserverpro.config property: pageHeaderText

data.name: Cfg_sendEmailOnError_Bdy
data.value:
When checked, the designated administrator is sent a detailed report when a web site error occurs. The e-mail settings must be configured, including specifying an SMTP server, for this option to work.

galleryserverpro.config property: sendEmailOnError

data.name: Cfg_smtpPort_Bdy
data.value:
Specify the port number to use when sending SMTP mail. This setting is useful when the web server is behind a proxy.

This value is stored in the config file galleryserverpro.config. If you wish to use the SMTP port specified in web.config (either explicitly assigned in this web application or inherited from a parent application), you may leave this field blank. Gallery Server Pro will automatically use the value specified in the system.net mailSettings section if no value is specified here.

If not specified, and if no value is defined (or inherited) in web.config, the default port 25 is used.

galleryserverpro.config property: smtpServerPort

data.name: Cfg_smtpServer_Bdy
data.value:
Specify the IP address or name of the SMTP server used to send e-mails (e.g. 127.0.0.1, Godzilla, mail.yourisp.com).

If you leave it blank, Gallery Server Pro will use the SMTP server specified in the system.net-mailSettings section of web.config (both the explicit web.config for this application and the inherited values from web.config files further up the hierarchy). If no value is found in web.config, Gallery Server Pro will attempt to use the local server.

galleryserverpro.config property: smtpServer

data.name: Cfg_defaultAlbumThumbnailBackgroundColor_Bdy
data.value:
The background color of the thumbnail image. It can be specified as hex (e.g. #336699), RGB (e.g. 127,55,95), or one of the System.Color.KnownColor enum values (e.g. Maroon).

galleryserverpro.config property: emptyAlbumThumbnailBackgroundColor

data.name: Cfg_defaultAlbumThumbnailFontColor_Bdy
data.value:
The color of the text. It can be specified as hex (e.g. #336699), RGB (e.g. 127,55,95), or one of the System.Color.KnownColor enum values (e.g. Maroon).

galleryserverpro.config property: emptyAlbumThumbnailFontColor

data.name: Cfg_defaultAlbumThumbnailFontName_Bdy
data.value:
The font in which the text on a thumbnail is displayed. The font must be installed on the web server. If the font is not installed, a generic sans serif font will be substituted.

galleryserverpro.config property: emptyAlbumThumbnailFontName

data.name: Cfg_defaultAlbumThumbnailFontSize_Bdy
data.value:
The size, in pixels, of the font used to display the text. Valid values: 6 - 100.

galleryserverpro.config property: emptyAlbumThumbnailFontSize

data.name: Cfg_defaultAlbumThumbnailText_Bdy
data.value:
The text to appear on a thumbnail image.

galleryserverpro.config property: emptyAlbumThumbnailText

data.name: Cfg_defaultAlbumThumbnailWidthToHeightRatio_Bdy
data.value:
The ratio of the width to height of the thumbnail image. The length of the longest side of the image is set by the MaxThumbnailLength property, and the length of the remaining side is calculated using this ratio.

A ratio of more than 1.00 results in the width being greater than the height (landscape), while a ratio less than 1.00 results in the width being less than the height (portrait).

Example: If MaxThumbnailLength = 115 and the aspect ratio = 1.50, the width of the default thumbnail image is 115 and the height is 77 (115/1.50).

galleryserverpro.config property: emptyAlbumThumbnailWidthToHeightRatio

data.name: Cfg_maxAlbumThumbnailTitleDisplayLength_Bdy
data.value:
The maximum number of characters to display when showing the title of an album in thumbnail view.

galleryserverpro.config property: maxAlbumThumbnailTitleDisplayLength

data.name: Cfg_maxAlbumThumbnailTitleDisplayLength_Hdr
data.value: Album title thumbnail - max number of characters

data.name: Cfg_maxMediaObjectThumbnailTitleDisplayLength_Bdy
data.value:
The maximum number of characters to display when showing the title of a media object in a thumbnail view.

galleryserverpro.config property: maxMediaObjectThumbnailTitleDisplayLength

data.name: Cfg_maxMediaObjectThumbnailTitleDisplayLength_Hdr
data.value: Media object thumbnail title character max

data.name: Cfg_mediaObjectPath_Bdy
data.value:
The path to a directory containing the media objects. The path may be:

  • Relative to the root of the web application (e.g. \\\\gs\\\\mediaobjects)
  • A full path to a local resource (e.g. C:\\\\mymedia)
  • A UNC path to a local or network resource (e.g. \\\\\\\\mynas\\\\media)

Mapped drives present a security risk and are not supported. The initial and trailing slashes are optional.

Note: Changing the location does not move objects to the new location. If you change this setting, you should synchronize the database (from actions menu, choose synchronize) so that the records match the files in the directory. An alternative to synchronizing is to use a tool such as Windows Explorer to manually copy the files from the old location to the new location.

galleryserverpro.config property: mediaObjectPath

data.name: Cfg_mediaObjectTransitionDuration_Bdy
data.value:
The duration of the transition effect, in seconds, when navigating between media objects. This setting has no effect when the media object transition effect is set to None.

galleryserverpro.config property: mediaObjectTransitionDuration

data.name: Cfg_mediaObjectTransitionType_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the visual transition effect to use when browsing from one media object to the next.

galleryserverpro.config property: mediaObjectTransitionType

data.name: Cfg_optimizedPath_Bdy
data.value:
The path to a directory where Gallery Server should store the compressed images of media objects. If no path is specified, the directory containing the original media object is used to store the thumbnail image.

You can use the same directory as your original media object files or a different one. Many users prefer to store the thumbnail and compressed images in a separate directory to keep the directories containing the original files clean.

The path may be:

  • Relative to the root of the web application (e.g. \\\\gs\\\\mediaobjects)
  • A full path to a local resource (e.g. C:\\\\mymedia)
  • A UNC path to a local or network resource (e.g. \\\\\\\\mynas\\\\media)

Mapped drives present a security risk and are not supported. The initial and trailing slashes are optional.

Note: Changing the location does not move objects to the new location. If you change this setting, you should synchronize the database (from actions menu, choose synchronize) to generate new images in the new location. An alternative to synchronizing is to use a tool such as Windows Explorer to manually copy the files from the old location to the new location.

galleryserverpro.config property: optimizedPath

data.name: Cfg_thumbnailPath_Bdy
data.value:
The path to a directory where Gallery Server should store the thumbnail images of media objects. If no path is specified, the directory containing the original media object is used to store the thumbnail image.

You can use the same directory as your original media object files or a different one. Many users prefer to store the thumbnail and compressed images in a separate directory to keep the directories containing the original files clean.

The path may be:

  • Relative to the root of the web application (e.g. \\\\gs\\\\mediaobjects)
  • A full path to a local resource (e.g. C:\\\\mymedia)
  • A UNC path to a local or network resource (e.g. \\\\\\\\mynas\\\\media)

Mapped drives present a security risk and are not supported. The initial and trailing slashes are optional.

Note: Changing the location does not move objects to the new location. If you change this setting, you should synchronize the database (from actions menu, choose synchronize) to generate new thumbnails in the new location. An alternative to synchronizing is to use a tool such as Windows Explorer to manually copy the files from the old location to the new location.

galleryserverpro.config property: thumbnailPath

data.name: Admin_Images_About_Compressed_Images_Bdy
data.value:
When you add an image or synchronize the database, Gallery Server Pro creates a compressed version of an image (in JPG format) when at least one of these is true:

  • The file size of the image is larger than a designated value (called the compression limit)
  • The length of the image\\'s longest side is larger than a designated length (called the compressed image length)

Example: You upload a 1656 px by 1242 px JPG image that is 800 KB. You have Gallery Server Pro configured with these settings:

  • The compression limit is 50 KB.
  • The compression quality setting is 70.
  • The compressed image length is 640 px.

Since the image is larger than the 50 KB limit, a compressed copy of the original is created with a quality setting of 70 and the dimensions 640 px by 480 px.

NOTE: In this example, even if the original image is less than 50 KB, a compressed image is still created, because the length of its longest side - 1656 px - is longer than the compressed image length setting (640 px).

data.name: Cfg_applyWatermarkToThumbnails_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether to apply the text and/or image watermark to thumbnail images. This property is ignored if watermarking is disabled.

galleryserverpro.config property: applyWatermarkToThumbnails

data.name: Cfg_applyWatermark_Bdy
data.value:
Applies a watermark to compressed and original images. If checked, both the text and the image specified below are applied to images.

Note: If a user belongs to a role with "View images without watermarks" permission, then no watermarks are applied to images for this user, regardless of this setting.

galleryserverpro.config property: applyWatermark

data.name: Cfg_autoStartMediaObject_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether a video, audio or other dynamic media object will automatically start playing in the user\\'s browser. This setting is ignored if the browser plug-in does not support this feature.

galleryserverpro.config property: autoStartMediaObject

data.name: Cfg_defaultAudioPlayerHeight_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the height, in pixels, of the browser plug-in that plays an audio file.

galleryserverpro.config property: defaultAudioPlayerHeight

data.name: Cfg_defaultAudioPlayerWidth_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the width, in pixels, of the browser plug-in that plays an audio file.

galleryserverpro.config property: defaultAudioPlayerWidth

data.name: Cfg_defaultGenericObjectHeight_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the height, in pixels, of the browser plug-in that displays a generic media object.

This is used primarily for Shockwave Flash objects, but applies to any file with a mime type (a) that is not an image, video, or audio object, and (b) for which there are rendering instructions in the mediaObjects section of the configuration file galleryserverpro.config.

This value is mapped to the dynamic {Height} property that can be used in the htmlOutput attribute of the browser XML element in galleryserverpro.config. An alternative to setting the value here is to specify the desired value directly in the configuration file instead of using {Height}. This can be useful if, for example, you want all Shockwave files rendered at one size and generic media objects of another type to be rendered at another size.

galleryserverpro.config property: defaultGenericObjectHeight

data.name: Cfg_defaultGenericObjectWidth_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the width, in pixels, of the browser plug-in that displays a generic media object.

This is used primarily for Shockwave Flash objects, but applies to any file with a mime type (a) that is not an image, video, or audio object, and (b) for which there are rendering instructions in the mediaObjects section of the configuration file galleryserverpro.config.

This value is mapped to the dynamic {Width} property that can be used in the htmlOutput attribute of the browser XML element in galleryserverpro.config. An alternative to setting the value here is to specify the desired value directly in the configuration file instead of using {Width}. This can be useful if, for example, you want all Shockwave files rendered at one size and generic media objects of another type to be rendered at another size.

galleryserverpro.config property: defaultGenericObjectWidth

data.name: Cfg_defaultVideoPlayerHeight_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the height, in pixels, of the browser plug-in that plays a video file.

galleryserverpro.config property: defaultVideoPlayerHeight

data.name: Cfg_defaultVideoPlayerWidth_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the width, in pixels, of the browser plug-in that plays a video file.

galleryserverpro.config property: defaultVideoPlayerWidth

data.name: Cfg_maxOptimizedLength_Bdy
data.value:
The length (in pixels) of the longest edge of the compressed image that Gallery Server Pro creates when an image is added. The length of the shorter side is calculated automatically based on the aspect ratio of the image.

This value is also used to determine if a compressed version of an image needs to be created. If you add an image and the length of its longest side is greater than this value, a compressed version is created.

galleryserverpro.config property: maxOptimizedLength

data.name: Cfg_optimizedImageJpegQuality_Bdy
data.value:
The quality level that compressed JPG images are created with. Valid values are 1 - 100, with 1 being the worst quality (smallest file size) and 100 being the best quality (largest file size).

galleryserverpro.config property: optimizedImageJpegQuality

data.name: Cfg_optimizedImageTriggerSizeKB_Bdy
data.value:
The size (in KB) above which an image is compressed to create a compressed (optimized) version. If an image\\'s file size is larger than this value, a bandwidth-friendly, compressed version is created. If an image\\'s file size is smaller than the value you specify, no compressed version is created.

The original image is never altered or deleted, regardless of this setting. (Rotating is the only function that modifies the original image.)

This setting is applied: (a) when new images are added to the gallery and (b) during synchronization if the "Overwrite existing compressed images" option is selected.

galleryserverpro.config property: optimizedImageTriggerSizeKB

data.name: Cfg_originalImageJpegQuality_Bdy
data.value:
The quality level at which original JPG images are saved. This setting is only used when the original is modified by the user, such as rotation. Valid values are 1 - 100, with 1 being the worst quality (smallest file size) and 100 being the best quality (largest file size).

galleryserverpro.config property: originalImageJpegQuality

data.name: Cfg_thumbnailClickShowsOriginal_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether the original image or the compressed image is displayed when the user clicks the thumbnail of an image. If unchecked, the compressed image, if it exists, is shown instead.

galleryserverpro.config property: thumbnailClickShowsOriginal

data.name: Cfg_watermarkImageLocation_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the location for the watermark image on the recipient image.

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkImageLocation

data.name: Cfg_watermarkImageOpacityPercent_Bdy
data.value:
The opacity of the watermark image. Valid values are 0 - 100, 0 being completely transparent and 100 completely opaque.

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkImageOpacityPercent

data.name: Cfg_watermarkImagePath_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the full or relative path to a watermark image to be applied to the recipient image. Most common image types, such as JPG, GIF, BMP, TIF, and PNG are accepted.

Relative paths are relative to the root of the web application. The directory-separating character can be either a forward or backward slash, and, for relative paths, the initial slash is optional.

Leave this setting blank if no image watermark is desired.

Examples:

  • /images/mywatermark.jpg
  • images/mywatermark.gif
  • \\\\images\\\\mywatermark.bmp
  • images\\\\mywatermark.tif
  • C:\\\\images\\\\mywatermark.png

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkImagePath

data.name: Cfg_watermarkImageWidthPercent_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the percent of the overall width of the recipient image that should be covered with the watermark image. The size of the image is automatically scaled to achieve the desired width. Valid values are 0 - 100.

For example, a value of 50 means the watermark image is 50% as wide as the recipient image.

A value of 0 turns off this feature and causes the image to be rendered at its actual size.

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkImageWidthPercent

data.name: Cfg_watermarkTextColor_Bdy
data.value:
The color of the watermark text. It can be specified as hex (e.g. #336699), RGB (e.g. 127,55,95), or one of the System.Color.KnownColor enum values (e.g. Maroon).

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkTextColor

data.name: Cfg_watermarkTextFontName_Bdy
data.value:
The font used for the watermark text. If the font is not installed on the web server, a generic sans serif font will be substituted.

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkTextFontName

data.name: Cfg_watermarkTextFontSize_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the height, in pixels, of the watermark text. Valid values are 1 - 10000.

Note: This value is ignored if the watermark text width percentage is non-zero.

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkTextFontSize

data.name: Cfg_watermarkTextLocation_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the location for the watermark text on the recipient image.

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkTextLocation

data.name: Cfg_watermarkTextOpacityPercent_Bdy
data.value:
The opacity of the watermark text. This is a value from 0 to 100, with 0 being invisible and 100 being solid, with no transparency.

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkTextOpacityPercent

data.name: Cfg_watermarkTextWidthPercent_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the percent of the overall width of the recipient image that should be covered with the watermark text. The size of the text is automatically scaled up or down to achieve the desired width. Valid values are 0 - 100.

This setting overrides the watermark font size setting. To disable this setting so that the watermark font size is enabled, set this value to zero.

For example, a value of 50 means the text is 50% as wide as the recipient image.

The text is never rendered in a font smaller than 4 pixels, so in cases of long text it may stretch wider than the percentage specified in this setting.

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkTextWidthPercent

data.name: Cfg_watermarkText_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the text to apply to images in the gallery. The text is applied in a single line. Leave this setting blank if no text watermark is desired.

galleryserverpro.config property: watermarkText

data.name: Cfg_maxThumbnailLength_Bdy
data.value:
The length (in pixels) of the longest edge of the thumbnail image that Gallery Server Pro creates when an image is added. The length of the shorter side is calculated automatically based on the aspect ratio of the image.

After changing this value, regenerate new thumbnail images by running the synchronize function, making sure to select the option Overwrite existing thumbnail images.

galleryserverpro.config property: maxThumbnailLength

data.name: UC_Album_Header_Album_Is_Private_Icon_Tooltip
data.value: This is a private album that is not visible to anonymous users

data.name: UC_Album_Header_Edit_Album_Is_Private_Info_Bdy
data.value:
By default, anonymous users can view all albums. This is because the roles and their assigned permissions apply only to logged on users.

You can hide some or all albums from anonymous users by setting them as private. When users log on, the normal security roles take over and this setting is ignored.

Setting an album as private automatically causes all of its child albums to be private, and they cannot be made un-private.

Note: If you want to require users to log on to see all the albums in the entire gallery, a better approach is to disable anonymous browsing in the Site Admin area.
data.comment: <2009.05.13> This text is the same as Task_Create_Album_Make_Private_Album_Bdy

data.name: Task_Synch_IncludeChildAlbums_Hlp_Bdy
data.value:
When checked, Gallery Server Pro will recursively synchronize any descendant albums in addition to synchronizing the current album. Leave unchecked if you only want to synchronize the current album, not any descendent albums.

If the current album does not contain any descendant albums, this setting has no effect.

data.name: Task_Synch_OverwriteCompressed_Hlp_Bdy
data.value:
When checked, new compressed images are created for each media object, overwriting any existing compressed images.

If unchecked, a compressed image is created only if it does not exist.

Synchronizing the database will run slightly faster if you leave this option unchecked.

data.name: Task_Synch_OverwriteThumbnails_Hlp_Bdy
data.value:
When checked, new thumbnail images are created for each media object, overwriting any existing thumbnails.

If unchecked, a thumbnail is created only if it does not exist.

Synchronizing the database will run slightly faster if you leave this option unchecked.

data.name: Task_Synch_Progress_ETL_1_of_5
data.comment: <2007.12.08> This text is part of a series of 5 resources that are concatenated to form the estimated time left string during a synchronization. Example: "1 hours 3 min 10 secs (10 of 6734 objects synchronized)" Make sure the strings have a leading and trailing space as needed.

data.name: Task_Synch_Progress_ETL_2_of_5
data.comment: <2007.12.08> See comment for Task_Synch_Progress_ETL_1_of_5

data.name: Task_Synch_Progress_ETL_3_of_5
data.comment: <2007.12.08> See comment for Task_Synch_Progress_ETL_1_of_5

data.name: Task_Synch_Progress_ETL_4_of_5
data.comment: <2007.12.08> See comment for Task_Synch_Progress_ETL_1_of_5

data.name: Task_Synch_Progress_ETL_5_of_5

data.name: Task_Synch_RegenerateMetadata_Hlp_Bdy
data.value:
When checked, metadata that was extracted from images when they were first added to Gallery Server Pro are replaced with the current metadata in the original image file. Metadata includes items such as camera model, shutter speed, title, and keywords.

For example, this is useful if you used a program like Vista Photo Gallery to add keywords to the image files and you want Gallery Server Pro to retrieve this information to aid in searching.

This setting has no effect on non-image media objects.

Note: Metadata that may exist in the original image files are not replicated to the thumbnail and compressed versions. If you delete the original versions of photos using the Delete high-res images command, that means there is no metadata to extract during subsequent synchronizations. The consequence of this is that checking this option after you have deleted the original images will cause you to lose the metadata that was extracted from the original files. Therefore, it is recommended to leave this option unchecked when you synchronize an album whose original, high resolution photos have been deleted.

data.name: Task_Synch_RegenerateMetadata_Text
data.value: Re-import metadata for existing images (replaces previously imported metadata)

data.name: Cfg_allowUnspecifiedMimeTypes_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether Gallery Server Pro is allowed to manage file types not explicitly specified in the MIME types list. When unchecked, only files with an extension in the list below and marked as enabled are allowed. When checked, Gallery Server Pro accepts all file types regardless of their file extension.

For maximum security, leave this unchecked and enable only those file types you want to include in the Gallery Server Pro gallery.

galleryserverpro.config property: allowUnspecifiedMimeTypes

data.name: Task_Synch_Options_Hlp_Bdy
data.value:
Each album in Gallery Server Pro has a corresponding physical directory on the web server\\'s hard drive. The synchronization procedure updates the Gallery Server Pro data store with information about the media objects in this directory.

Only those files with file extensions that are enabled are managed by Gallery Server Pro. You can edit this list in the Media Objects Types admin page or in the configuration file galleryserverpro.config.

When should you synchronize? You might want to synchronize when:

  • You just installed Gallery Server Pro and you want to load the data store with media objects without using the Add objects command. Make sure your media files are copied into the media objects directory before synchronizing. This directory is specified in the Media Objects - General page and in the configuration file galleryserverpro.config.
  • You added, moved, copied, or deleted objects using Windows Explorer instead of the Gallery Server Pro interface, causing the database to become out of synch with the media files on the web server\\'s hard drive.
  • You used a third party program like PhotoShop to alter one or more media files, and you want Gallery Server Pro to recreate the thumbnail and compressed image files.
  • You changed a configuration setting and want Gallery Server Pro to process all media objects with the new setting. For example, you may have changed the compressed image size, enabled or disabled a file extension, or moved the thumbnail storage directory to a new location.
  • A bug in Gallery Server Pro has caused the database to become out of synch with the object files on the web server\\'s hard drive.

data.name: Admin_Config_Security_Ex_Msg
data.value: Attention: These options are read only because Gallery Server Pro does not have write permission to the file that stores configuration data ({0}). You have two choices: (1) Manually update the file or (2) give the IIS application pool identity write permission to this file (by default this is the ASPNET user in IIS 5 and 5.1, Network Service in IIS 6 and 7, and IIS AppPool\DefaultAppPool in IIS 7.5).

data.name: Task_Add_Objects_ZipOption_Bdy
data.value:
Normally, the contents of a ZIP file are extracted and the original ZIP file is discarded. Check this option to treat ZIP files as a media object and allow them to be viewed and downloaded. When checked, the ZIP file is added to the media object gallery and the contents of the ZIP file are ignored.

This option is disabled if the ZIP file extension is disabled in the Media Object Types page in the Site Administration settings.

data.name: Task_Add_Objects_ZipOption_Hdr

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_AddAlbum_Bdy
data.value:
This permission allows a user to add an album.

Note: When moving or copying an album, users must have this permission on the destination album.

Note: When a user moves or copies an album, any media objects within the album are also transferred regardless of whether the user has Add media object permission on the destination album.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_AddMediaObject_Bdy
data.value:
This permission gives a user the ability to add media objects such as images, videos, audio files, and documents. Only those media objects that are enabled on the Media Object Types page can be added.

Note: A user must have both Add media object permission and Add album permission in order to add a ZIP file that contains one or more directories, since Gallery Server Pro attempts to convert the directories to albums.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_AdminSite_Bdy
data.value: This permission provides unrestricted access to all functionality in Gallery Server Pro. This is the only permission that applies to all albums in the gallery and cannot be selectively applied to individual albums.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_DeleteChildAlbum_Bdy
data.value:
This permission allows the deletion of a child album, but not the top level album this permission is applied to.

If the deleted album contains media objects, they are also deleted, even if the user does not have Delete media object permission.

Note: When moving an album, users must have this permission on the source album, as moving can be thought of as deleting an album from one location and adding it to another. (The user must also have permission to add an album to the destination album.)

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_DeleteMediaObject_Bdy
data.value:
This permission allows the deletion of a media object.

Note: When moving a media object, users must have this permission on the source album, as moving can be thought of as deleting an object from one location and adding it to another. (The user must also have permission to add a media object to the destination album.)

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_EditAlbum_Bdy
data.value: This permission allows a user to edit album information, such as the title, summary, begin and end dates, the assigned thumbnail, and the sequence of media objects and child albums.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_EditMediaObject_Bdy
data.value: This permission allows a user to edit a media object\\'s title. For images, it also allows rotation and the deletion of the original, high resolution image (if it exists).

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_HideWatermark_Bdy
data.value: This permission causes images to be shown to the user without the watermark applied. If a user belongs to more than one role with conflicting values, then watermarks are not shown. This permission is ignored if the watermark functionality is disabled for the gallery.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
Security in Gallery Server Pro consists of creating roles with the desired permissions applied to specific albums. Users are then assigned to one or more of these roles.

The default System Administrator role provides administrative privileges to the entire gallery. You can create additional roles with specific permissions that target individual albums. For example, you might create a role named DavidRole that has view/add/edit/delete permission to an album named Photos by David. Another role named MargaretRole might have view/add/edit/delete permission to the Photos by Margaret album. Then you create two users - David and Margaret - and assign each to the respective role. To give these users view-only access to the rest of the albums while retaining add/edit/delete permission to their original album, create a new role named ReadOnlyRole with view permissions for all albums, and then add this role to each user.

When a role is applied to an album, it is automatically applied to all child albums. When an album is added, moved, or copied to a new location, it inherits any role permissions from the containing album.

Gallery Server Pro will give a user permission to perform an activity if any of the user\\'s roles contain the requested permission, even if the others do not. For example, say a user belongs to three roles. Two of the roles do not have Delete album permission but the third one does. In this case, the user is given permission to delete the album that is specified in the role with the Delete album permission.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_Synchronize_Bdy
data.value:
This permission provides the ability to synchronize the media object files on the web server\\'s hard drive with the records in the data store.

Note: If a user has the ability to edit the media objects directory outside the security boundary of Gallery Server Pro (such as using a utility like Windows Explorer), and the user also has Synchronize permission here, he or she effectively has the ability to add and delete albums and media objects, even if those permissions are not included in a user\\'s role.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_ViewHiResImage_Bdy
data.value: This permission provides read only access to the original, high resolution versions of images, if they exist.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_ViewObject_Bdy
data.value: This permission provides a read only view of photos, videos, and other media objects. Note that it does not give access to the original, high resolution versions of images (if they exist).

data.name: Admin_Manage_Users_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
User accounts are used to control access to albums and gallery management functions. By default, Gallery Server Pro allows anonymous browsing of all albums but requires that users log in to create albums, add media objects, and perform administrative tasks.

Note: You can disable anonymous browsing on the Site Settings - General page.

Users are assigned to one or more roles. Use the manage roles page to configure the roles with the desired permission. Then use this page to assign each user to the appropriate role(s).

Gallery Server Pro will give a user permission to perform an activity if any of the user\\'s roles contain the requested permission, even if the others do not. For example, say a user belongs to three roles. Two of the roles do not have Delete album permission but the third one does. In this case, the user is given permission to delete the album that is specified in the role with the Delete album permission.

data.name: Admin_MimeTypes_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
Use this page to manage the types of files Gallery Server Pro manages. By default only files with a .jpg or .jpeg file extension are allowed.

If you disable a file type that has existing media objects in the gallery, those objects will be removed from the gallery during the next synchronization (the files will not be deleted, however).

To add a file extension not in this list, you can edit the list directly in the configuration file config/galleryserverpro.config.

data.name: Installer_Upgrade_ReadyToUpgrade_Permission_Warning
data.value: Note: The upgrade script is executed under the credentials in the connection string in web.config. Since the script may alter database objects, it could require permissions that are not currently granted to the login. If you get an error saying that you do not have permission to execute the SQL, use SQL Management Studio to increase the permissions granted to the login or temporarily replace the credentials in web.config with a login that has the appropriate permission. Alternatively, you can manually execute the SQL script instead of running this upgrade wizard.

data.name: Installer_Upgrade_Welcome_Hdr

data.name: Search_Popup_Help_Bdy
data.value:
The search functionality in Gallery Server Pro allows one to find all objects that contain the search criteria. The following properties are included in the search:

  • Album title and summary
  • Media object caption and file name
  • Media object metadata, such as camera model, shutter speed, title, etc.

An object is considered a match if all search words match an album or media object. For example, if one searches for desert mountain, only those albums or media objects that contain both desert and mountain are returned. If the search words are contained in quotation marks, such as "desert mountain", then the phrase must exactly match.

The contents of documents such as PDF files are not searched.

Only those objects for which the current user has authorization to view are returned in the search results.

Since the search function includes the metadata extracted from images, you can perform some pretty powerful searches. For example, to see all your photos that were shot at -0.5 step compensation, search for "-0.5 step". You may need to adjust the text depending on your camera.

data.name: Task_Add_Objects_External_Object_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
You can add items to your gallery that are hosted on the internet or can be referenced with HTML. Here are some examples:

  • YouTube videos
  • Videos hosted at silverlight.live.com
  • HTML that links to an image
  • Entire HTML files linked from an iframe

data.name: Task_Add_Objects_Local_Media_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
You can upload one or more files to the current album. The file must be a type that is enabled for the gallery, and the total file size of all files must be less than {0:N0} KB.

If you specify a ZIP file, its contents are extracted and imported into the gallery. If the ZIP file contains directories, they are converted to albums. For example, you may upload a single zip file containing several directories and hundreds of media objects.

You can override automatic ZIP file extraction by selecting the checkbox on this web page labeled "Treat ZIP files as media objects and do not extract contents".

data.name: Task_Add_Objects_Local_Media_Overview_Hdr
data.value: Add media files to your gallery

data.name: Task_Add_Objects_All_Adding_Types_Disabled_Msg

data.name: Admin_MediaObjects_AllowAddExternalContent_Label
data.value: Allow adding links to external content (such as YouTube videos)

data.name: Cfg_AllowAddExternalContent_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates whether users can add a link to external content, such as a YouTube video. Unchecking this setting causes the External Content tab on the Add objects web page to be hidden.

Note: Since external content is often snippets of HTML, you must enable the option to allow users to enter HTML to take full advantage of this feature. This setting can be found on the User Settings page in the Site Admin area.

Users must also be authenticated and a member of a role with AllowAddMediaObject or AllowAdministerSite permission in order to add external links.

If this setting is disabled, and the Upload media files setting is also disabled, the only way to add media objects is through synchronizing.

galleryserverpro.config property: allowAddExternalContent

data.name: Cfg_AllowAddLocalContent_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates whether users are allowed to upload media files, such as photos, audio, and video. Unchecking this setting causes the Local Media tab on the Add objects web page to be hidden.

Users must also be authenticated and a member of a role with AllowAddMediaObject or AllowAdministerSite permission in order to upload files.

If this setting is disabled, and the Link to external content setting is also disabled, the only way to add media objects is through synchronizing.

galleryserverpro.config property: allowAddLocalContent

data.name: Cfg_MaxUploadSize_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates the maximum size, in kilobytes, of the files that can be uploaded using the Add Objects web page. Use this setting to keep users from uploading very large files and to help guard against Denial of Service (DOS) attacks. A value of zero (0) indicates there is no restriction on upload size (unlimited).

This value applies to the content length of the entire upload request, not just the file. For example, if this value is 1024 KB and the user attempts to upload two 800 KB images, the request will fail because the total content length is larger than 1024 KB. This setting is not used during synchronization.

galleryserverpro.config property: maxUploadSize

data.name: Admin_BackupRestore_Backup_Overview_Bdy
data.value:
Use this tool to create an XML backup file containing the data in your database. This file may be used to transfer your data to another server, restore a gallery after a failure, or convert your data storage to another provider (for example, from SQLite to SQL Server).

Note: The backup/restore functionality does not support the use of more than one data provider in the same web application. The default installation uses a single provider for all data, so this limitation only affects advanced users who changed the settings. The backup file includes data ONLY from the data provider specified in the defaultProvider setting in the dataProvider section of galleryserverpro.config.

For example, if you are storing gallery data in SQLite (galleryserverpro.config has the value dataProvider defaultProvider="SQLiteGalleryServerProProvider") and membership data in SQL Server (web.config is specifying SqlMembershipProvider, SqlRoleProvider, and SqlProfileProvider), your backup file will only contain the data that is in SQLite. That is, it will have your gallery data (media objects and albums), but not your users.

data.name: Admin_BackupRestore_ExportGalleryData_Bdy
data.value:
Select this option to include gallery data, such as titles, captions, and metadata in the backup file.

Note: Selecting this option DOES NOT back up media object files. To back these up, use a utility like Windows Explorer to copy them from your media objects directory.

data.name: Admin_BackupRestore_ExportGalleryData_Hdr
data.value: Export media object and album data

data.name: Admin_BackupRestore_ExportUserAccounts_Bdy
data.value:
Select this option to include the ASP.NET membership data in the backup file. This includes the users, roles, and applications stored in the membership tables (the tables whose names start with "aspnet_").

When selected, ALL membership data is exported. If you using these tables to manage membership for other applications, be aware that the data for these other applications are also included in the backup file.

Note: The file does not contain your media object files. To back these up, use a utility like Windows Explorer to copy them from your media objects directory.

data.name: Installer_DataProvider_Dtl1
data.value: Choose the data provider to use for storing the gallery data. SQLite is a lightweight, easy to manage open source database that is completely self contained within Gallery Server Pro. SQL Server, including the free Express version, offers high performance and reliability, but requires a separate installation and a higher level of skill to manage.

data.value: You can change to a different provider after installation by using the Backup / Restore function.

data.name: Installer_DataProvider_SQLite_Not_Available_Msg
data.value: The SQLite data provider is not listed in the web.config and/or galleryserverpro.config files, so it is not available. You may have intentionally done this to allow Gallery Server Pro to work in Medium Trust. If you wish to use SQLite, edit web.config so that it specifies the SQLite providers for Membership, Roles, and Profile, and edit galleryserverpro.config so that it specifies SQLite for data, then restart this wizard. You may need to restart the IIS application pool for the changes to take effect.

data.name: Installer_DataProvider_SQLite_And_SqlServer_Not_Available_Msg
data.value: Error: Web.config or galleryserverpro.config is missing configuration information for both SQLite and SQL Server providers for Membership, Roles, Profile, and data. Edit these files so that the desired providers are available. If necessary, revert to the original web.config and galleryserverpro.config files in the Gallery Server Pro download. You may need to restart the IIS application pool for the changes to take effect.

data.name: Installer_DataProvider_SqlServer_Not_Available_Msg
data.value: The SQL Server data provider is not listed in the web.config and/or galleryserverpro.config files, so it is not available. If you wish to use SQL Server, edit web.config so that it specifies the SQL Server providers for Membership, Roles, and Profile, and edit galleryserverpro.config so that it specifies SQL Server for data, then restart this wizard. You may need to restart the IIS application pool for the changes to take effect.

data.name: Installer_DataProvider_GalleryServerProConfig_Not_Updateable_InsufficientPermission
data.value: The installer does not have permission to modify {0}, which is required to configure the data provider. Do one of the following: (1) Give the IIS application pool identity write permission to galleryserverpro.config (by default this is the ASPNET user in IIS 5 and 5.1, Network Service in IIS 6 and 7, and IIS AppPool\DefaultAppPool in IIS 7.5) (2) Edit galleryserverpro.config manually so that the {1} provider is specified. You may need to restart the IIS application pool for the changes to take effect.

data.name: Installer_DataProvider_WebConfig_Not_UpdateableToSQLite_InsufficientPermission
data.value: The installer does not have permission to modify web.config, which is required to configure the data provider. Do one of the following: (1) Give the IIS application pool identity write permission to web.config (by default this is the ASPNET user in IIS 5 and 5.1, Network Service in IIS 6 and 7, and IIS AppPool\DefaultAppPool in IIS 7.5) (2) Edit web.config manually so that the SQLite providers are specified for membership, roles, and profile (3) Restore web.config to the version that shipped with Gallery Server Pro, which is pre-configured for SQLite. You may need to restart the IIS application pool for the changes to take effect.

data.name: Installer_DataProvider_WebConfig_Not_UpdateableToSqlServer_InsufficientPermission
data.value: The installer does not have permission to modify web.config, which is required to configure the data provider. Do one of the following: (1) Give the IIS application pool identity write permission to web.config (by default this is the ASPNET user in IIS 5 and 5.1, Network Service in IIS 6 and 7, and IIS AppPool\DefaultAppPool in IIS 7.5) (2) Edit web.config manually so that the SQL Server providers are specified for membership, roles, and profile (3) Replace web.config with the one named web_sqlserver_2.0.config (.NET 2.0) or web_sqlserver_3.5.config (.NET 3.5). They are both pre-configured for SQL Server. You may need to restart the IIS application pool for the changes to take effect.

data.name: Cfg_productKey_Bdy
data.value:
Gallery Server Pro is supported entirely through donations. In an effort to make donating as easy and convenient as possible, we ask that you return to galleryserverpro.com after an initial 30-day trial period to retrieve a product key. During this time, we ask that you provide a donation reflecting the value you are receiving from Gallery Server Pro.

Even if you choose not to donate, you can still get a valid product key.

If a product key is not entered within the trial period, the Site admin area becomes read-only and a watermark is applied to all images. Full functionality can be restored at any time by entering a product key.

data.name: Cfg_enableExceptionHandler_Bdy
data.value:
Select this option to use Gallery Server Pro\\'s own error handling routine to deal with all unexpected errors. Disable this option if you have an application-level error handler defined in web.config or global.asax that you want to use for unhandled exceptions. Errors are always logged in the error log, even if this setting is disabled.

galleryserverpro.config property: enableExceptionHandler

data.name: Cfg_showErrorDetails_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates whether to display the full details of an unhandled exception that occurs within the gallery. This can reveal sensitive information to the user, so it should only be used for debugging purposes. When unchecked, a generic error message is displayed. This setting has no effect if Error Handling is disabled. Full details are always stored in the error log, so it is recommended to disable this option and refer to the error log for more information.

galleryserverpro.config property: showErrorDetails

data.name: Cfg_maxNumberErrorItems_Bdy
data.value:
When enabled, Gallery Server Pro will limit the size of the error log to the number of errors specified in the textbox below. When the maximum size is reached, the oldest errors are deleted to make room for the new ones. Use this feature to keep a rolling history of errors.

galleryserverpro.config property: This property does not map directly to a setting in galleryserverpro.config. Instead, when disabled, the value zero is stored in maxNumberErrorItems. When enabled, the value specified in the Max number of error items textbox below is stored.

data.name: Task_Add_Objects_Discard_Original_Image_Bdy
data.value:
When selected, the original image file is deleted after the thumbnail and optimized images are created and the image metadata is extracted. This option can save a significant amount of hard drive space because the high resolution original is not retained.

This option affects only image files.

Note: The administrator may have made this option read-only.

data.value: Discard original file after creating compressed version (images only)

data.name: Task_Create_Album_Make_Private_Album_Bdy
data.value:
By default, anonymous users can view all albums. This is because the roles and their assigned permissions apply only to logged on users.

You can hide some or all albums from anonymous users by setting them as private. When users log on, the normal security roles take over and this setting is ignored.

Setting an album as private automatically causes all of its child albums to be private, and they cannot be made un-private.

Note: If you want to require users to log on to see all the albums in the entire gallery, a better approach is to disable anonymous browsing in the Site Admin area.

data.name: Cfg_allowAnonymousBrowsing_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates whether users can browse the gallery without logging in. When unchecked, users must log in with a valid account to view media objects.

galleryserverpro.config property: allowAnonymousBrowsing

data.name: Cfg_allowAnonymousHiResBrowsing_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates whether users can view the original, high resolution images without logging in. When unchecked, users must log in with a valid account to view media objects, and that account must belong to a role that allows viewing the high resolution images.

This setting is ignored when anonymous browsing is disabled.

galleryserverpro.config property: allowAnonymousHiResViewing

data.name: Cfg_allowAnonymousHiResBrowsing_Hdr
data.value: Allow anonymous browsing of high resolution images

data.name: Cfg_enableImageMetadata_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether Gallery Server Pro extracts and displays metadata from image files. When enabled, image metadata such as title, camera model, etc, are extracted from image files when they are uploaded by a user or added through the synchronization process. Users can view this metadata by clicking the toolbar button above the media object.

The following formats are supported: EXIF, XMP, tEXt, IFD, and IPTC.

Disabling this option causes the toolbar icon to be hidden, even if metadata has previously been extracted.

This option is relevant only for image media types.

galleryserverpro.config property: enableImageMetadata

data.name: Cfg_mediaObjectPathIsReadOnly_Bdy
data.value:
Gallery Server Pro helps you share and manage your media collection over the web. In some cases you may not want to allow it to make any changes to your media files. In other words, you want Gallery Server Pro to expose a read-only view of your collection.

When Gallery Server Pro is in read-only mode, users cannot create albums or upload files, nor can they move, copy or delete albums and media objects. That is, they cannot perform any action that modifies the original media files. However, users can synchronize, download, rearrange and edit captions, and administrators can change settings in the Site admin area, including managing users and roles.

There are several requirements that must be met before a gallery can be made read-only:

  • User albums must be disabled
  • The directory for the thumbnail and compressed images must be different than the original media objects directory
  • The option Synchronize directory names with album titles must be disabled

When a gallery is read-only, the only way to add or remove media objects is by manually updating the media objects directory with a tool like Windows Explorer and then running the synchronize function.

If this setting is enabled, it is recommended to configure the IIS application pool identity to have read-only access to the media objects directory as an additional safeguard. This helps guarantee that the web application cannot manipulate the media files.

galleryserverpro.config property: mediaObjectPathIsReadOnly

data.name: Cfg_optimizedFileNamePrefix_Bdy
data.value:
The string that is prepended to the optimized file name for images. This setting is only used for image media objects where a compressed image file is created.

For example, if an image named puppy.jpg is added, and this setting is zOpt_, the optimized image will be named zOpt_puppy.jpg.

NOTE: Any file named zOpt_puppy.jpg that already exists will be overwritten, so it is important to choose a value that, when prepended to media object file names, will not conflict with existing media objects.

NOTE: After changing this value, perform a synchronization so that new thumbnails are created with the new name and the old ones are deleted.

galleryserverpro.config property: optimizedFileNamePrefix

data.name: Cfg_sendEmailUsingSsl_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether e-mail functionality uses Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) to encrypt the connection. Select this option if your e-mail provider requires SSL.

galleryserverpro.config property: sendEmailUsingSsl

data.name: Cfg_synchAlbumTitleAndDirectoryName_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates whether to update the directory name corresponding to an album when the album\\'s title is changed. When true, modifying the title of an album causes the directory name to change to the same value. You may want to disable this if you have a directory structure that you do not want Gallery Server Pro to alter.

Note that even if this setting is disabled, directories will still be moved or copied when the user moves or copies an album. Also, Gallery Server Pro always modifies the directory name when it is necessary to make it unique within a parent directory. For example, this may happen if you give two sibling albums the same title or you move/copy an album into a directory containing another album with the same name.

This setting must be disabled when the gallery is configured to be read-only.

galleryserverpro.config property: synchAlbumTitleAndDirectoryName

data.name: Cfg_synchAlbumTitleAndDirectoryName_Hdr
data.value: Synchronize directory names with album titles

data.name: Cfg_thumbnailFileNamePrefix_Bdy
data.value:
The string that is prepended to the thumbnail file name for each media object.

For example, if an image named puppy.jpg is added, and this setting is zThumb_, the thumbnail image will be named zThumb_puppy.jpg.

NOTE: Any file named zThumb_puppy.jpg that already exists will be overwritten, so it is important to choose a value that, when prepended to media object file names, will not conflict with existing media objects.

NOTE: After changing this value, perform a synchronization so that new thumbnails are created with the new name and the old ones are deleted.

galleryserverpro.config property: thumbnailFileNamePrefix

data.name: Cfg_thumbnailImageJpegQuality_Bdy
data.value:
The quality level that thumbnail JPG images are created with. Valid values are 1 - 100, with 1 being the worst quality (smallest file size) and 100 being the best quality (largest file size).

galleryserverpro.config property: thumbnailImageJpegQuality

data.name: Admin_Albums_EnablePaging_Lbl
data.value: Enable paging when viewing the contents of an album

data.name: Admin_Error_Invalid_PageSize_Msg
data.value: Number of items must be greater than zero.

data.name: Admin_MediaObjects_EnableMoZipDownload_Label
data.value: Allow downloading multiple media files in ZIP archive

data.name: Cfg_enableMoDownload_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether Gallery Server Pro shows a download button in the toolbar that appears above media objects.

Note that disabling this setting is not 100% effective in preventing a user from downloading a media object, since a user already has access if he or she can view it in the browser. The only effective method for ensuring users cannot download your media files is to use DRM protection, which is a feature that Gallery Server Pro does not provide.

galleryserverpro.config property: enableMediaObjectDownload

data.name: Cfg_enableMoZipDownload_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether users are allowed to download multiple media files in a ZIP archive. When enabled, a toolbar button appears above the media object, in the album summary section on the album view page, and in the Actions menu. This option is system wide and cannot be applied on a per-user or per-album basis.

galleryserverpro.config property: enableMediaObjectZipDownload

data.name: Cfg_enableMoZipDownload_Hdr
data.value: Allow downloading multiple media files in ZIP archive

data.name: Cfg_enablePermalink_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether Gallery Server Pro offers a permalink for a media object. When enabled, a toolbar button appears above the media object that displays a permanent hyperlink to that object. This hyperlink links directly to the media object and is a convenient way to share links with others.

This feature is necessary because AJAX callbacks are used as the user navigates the media objects in an album and the url in the browser\\'s address bar is not updated for each media object.

galleryserverpro.config property: enablePermalink

data.name: Cfg_enableSlideShow_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether slide show functionality is enabled. When enabled, a start/pause slideshow button is displayed in the toolbar that appears above a media object.

The length of time each image is shown before automatically moving to the next one is controlled by the slideshow interval setting.

Note that only images are shown during a slide show; other objects such as videos, audio files, and documents are skipped.

galleryserverpro.config property: enableSlideShow

data.name: Cfg_enableWpfMetadataExtraction_Bdy
data.value:
When enabled, metadata is extracted from image files using the Windows Presentation Foundation (WPF) classes available in .NET Framework 3.0 and higher. The WPF classes allow additional metadata to be extracted beyond those allowed by the .NET Framework 2.0, such as title, keywords, and rating.

This option requires that .NET Framework 3.0 or higher is installed on the web server and the web application is running in Full Trust.

galleryserverpro.config property: enableWpfMetadataExtraction

data.name: Cfg_enabledPaging_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates whether to limit the number of media objects to display at a time. When paging is enabled and an album has a large number of items, paging controls appear to assist the user in navigating to them. When disabled, all objects are displayed in an album.

galleryserverpro.config property: This property does not map directly to a setting in galleryserverpro.config. Instead, when disabled, the value zero is stored in pageSize. When enabled, the value specified for the page size below is stored.

data.name: Cfg_pagerLocation_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the location for the pager controls.

galleryserverpro.config property: pagerLocation

data.name: Cfg_pageSize_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the number of objects to display at a time.

galleryserverpro.config property: pageSize

data.value: Add new user accounts to these roles:

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_RedirectAfterLogin_Lbl
data.value: Always redirect to user's album after logging on

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_RequireEmailValidation_Lbl
data.value: Require e-mail validation to activate account

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_UseEmailForAccountName_Lbl
data.value: Use e-mail address for user name

data.name: Cfg_enableSelfRegistration_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether anonymous users are allowed to create accounts. If user albums are enabled, an album is created for each user.

galleryserverpro.config property: enableSelfRegistration

data.name: Cfg_enableUserAlbum_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether each user is assigned ownership to an album created solely for that user.

The album is created when the user account is created or when the user first logs in. The permissions assigned to the user for this album are copied from the template role _Album Owner Template. You can change the permissions in this role to control the default security access given to each user.

Disabling this option does not delete the user albums.

galleryserverpro.config property: enableUserAlbum

data.name: Cfg_redirectToUserAlbumAfterLogin_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether to redirect the user to his or her album after logging in. If disabled, the current page is re-loaded or, if there isn\\'t a page, the user is shown the top level album for which the user has view access.

galleryserverpro.config property: redirectToUserAlbumAfterLogin

data.name: Cfg_redirectToUserAlbumAfterLogin_Hdr
data.value: Redirect to user album after logging in

data.name: Cfg_requireEmailValidationForSelfRegisteredUser_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether e-mail verification is required when a user registers an account. When selected, the account is initially disabled and an e-mail is sent to the user with a verification link. When the user clicks the link, the user is approved.

If the option to require administrator approval for new accounts is enabled, then the user is not approved until an administrator activates the account.

Enabling this setting reduces spam activity and guarantees that a valid e-mail address is associated with the user.

When disabled, an e-mail address is not required and the user account is immediately created.

galleryserverpro.config property: requireEmailValidationForSelfRegisteredUser

data.name: Cfg_useEmailForAccountName_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies whether account names are primarily e-mail addresses. When disabled, the self registration wizard includes fields for both an account name and an e-mail address, but when enabled it requests only an e-mail address.

galleryserverpro.config property: useEmailForAccountName

data.name: Cfg_userAlbumNameTemplate_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the template to use for naming the album that is created for new users. The placeholder string {UserName}, if present, is replaced by the user\\'s account name.

galleryserverpro.config property: userAlbumNameTemplate

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_ShowOwnerRoles_Bdy
data.value:
The album owner and user album features use roles behind the scenes to manage the security access to the albums. These roles are automatically created when needed and always begin with the text Album Owner.

Typically an administrator does not interact with these roles, so they are hidden by default. Check this option to view them.

You may delete an owner role if it is no longer associated with an album or user. If you accidentally delete a role associated with a user album, it will be automatically recreated the next time the user logs on.

data.name: Admin_Manage_Roles_Show_Owner_Roles_Lbl
data.value: Show roles that support the album ownership and user album features

data.name: Admin_Manage_Users_Show_Album_Owner_Roles_Lbl
data.value: Show roles that support the album ownership and user album features

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_RequireAdminApproval_Lbl
data.value: Require administrator approval to activate account

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_Show_Album_Owner_Roles_Lbl
data.value: Show roles that support the album ownership and user album features

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_Show_All_Users_Lbl
data.value: Show all users, not just those with AllowAdministerSite permission

data.name: Admin_User_Settings_Users_To_Notify_For_New_Accounts_Lbl
data.value: Send an e-mail to the following users when an account is created:

data.name: Cfg_defaultRolesForSelfRegisteredUser_Bdy
data.value:
Visitors who register their own accounts can optionally be added to one or more roles when the account is created. For example, you might add them to a role that removes the watermark, gives them read-only access to the entire site, or permission to upload items to a particular album.

This setting applies ONLY to self-registered users. That is, when an administrator manually creates an account, these roles are not assigned to the user.

Note: If user albums are enabled, the user is automatically given full permission to his or her personal album, even if no roles are specified here.

galleryserverpro.config property: defaultRolesForSelfRegisteredUser

data.name: Cfg_requireApprovalForSelfRegisteredUser_Bdy
data.value:
Indicates whether an administrator must approve newly created accounts before the user can log on. When enabled, the account is disabled until it is approved by an administrator. (An administrator is a user belonging to a role with AllowAdministerSite permission.)

To receive an e-mail notification when a user creates an account, include your account in the new account notification setting in the User Accounts section. Note that when e-mail verification is enabled, the e-mail notification is not sent until the user validates the e-mail address.

galleryserverpro.config property: requireApprovalForSelfRegisteredUser

data.name: Cfg_userAlbumParentAlbumId_Bdy
data.value:
Specifies the album in which user albums are created.

If a different album is selected, existing user albums are not automatically moved. To move them to another album, use the standard functionality for moving albums.

galleryserverpro.config property: userAlbumParentAlbumId

data.name: Cfg_usersToNotifyWhenAccountIsCreated_Bdy
data.value:
Users specified here receive an e-mail notification when an account is created. This applies to both administrator-created or self-registered accounts.

To receive an e-mail, each user must have a valid e-mail address and e-mail functionality must be configured.

If self-registration is enabled with the e-mail validation option selected, then the e-mail is not sent until the new account holder validates the account from the verification e-mail.

galleryserverpro.config property: usersToNotifyWhenAccountIsCreated

Specifies whether to discard the original image when it is added to the gallery. This option, when enabled, helps reduce disk space usage.

This option applies only to images, and only when they are added through an upload or by synchronizing. Changing this setting does not affect existing media objects.

When unchecked, users still have the option to discard the original image on the Add Objects page by unchecking the corresponding checkbox.
